title: Publish v0.9.0
body: Waiting for `soketto` to be published before we can publish this.

title: No longer require fmt::Debug when not necessary
Allow injecting an existing connection in the RawSwarm
body:
Makes it possible to inject an already-open connection into the `RawSwarm`.

This is a step towards #1134. When we get a new connection through a relay, we want to inject it in the `RawSwarm` as if it was a full connection.

title: Kademlia: Send all pending RPCs for a peer on established connection.
body: This is a minimal patch extracted from https://github.com/libp2p/rust-libp2p/pull/1154 that may be worthwhile incorporating on its own. Currently, when a connection to a peer is established, only the first pending RPC found for that peer is sent, although there may be multiple (from concurrent queries). I chose the simplest possible fix (`if let` -> `while let`) as the list of pending RPCs is assumed to be small, if not empty. An alternative may be to partition the list into two new `SmallVec`s, keeping one and iterating over the other to send the RPC events, but I really can't say if that is worthwhile doing as I haven't benchmarked.

title: Kademlia: Fix premature query termination.
body: This is a minimal fix for https://github.com/libp2p/rust-libp2p/issues/1105 extracted from https://github.com/libp2p/rust-libp2p/pull/1154 that may be worthwhile incorporating on its own and potentially useful for https://github.com/libp2p/rust-libp2p/pull/1144 (context https://github.com/montekki/rust-libp2p/pull/1#issuecomment-497923800).

title: Some improvements to the docs of NetworkBehaviour
Reimplement the websocket transport.
body:
Actually two transports are implemented, one in the `framed` module whose output implements `Stream` and `Sink`, but not `AsyncRead` or `AsyncWrite`, and on top of that another transport which merely wraps the output of the former in a `RwStreamSink` to produce an output type which implements `AsyncRead` and `AsyncWrite`. The output of the `framed` transport produces and consumes just bytes which correspond to the actual application data in a websocket frame. (See https://github.com/libp2p/rust-libp2p/issues/1103 for details.)

The transport(s) now handle TLS, i.e. they use TLS for `/wss` multi-addresses (See https://github.com/libp2p/rust-libp2p/issues/1094 for details.)

I have created a version of the chat example to work with the websocket transport. If you want to try it you can find it here: https://gist.github.com/twittner/1c9ea9fcd538d5e6727cd6bb56c1a43d.

The transport uses the not yet published [soketto](https://github.com/paritytech/soketto) crate which is a heavily modified fork of the twist crate. If and when we agree to merge this PR soketto should be published to `crates.io` and the git reference in the `Cargo.toml` of `libp2p-websocket` should be replaced with a proper version number.

title: Add deflate protocol
body:
Add deflate protocol; fixes #955.

I hope I did this right, although I'm not 100% sure being so new to rust-libp2p and the surrounding ecosystem.

title: Update dependencies
body:
Based on https://deps.rs/repo/github/libp2p/rust-libp2p

This is technically a breaking change, because we expose `zeroize::Zeroize` in the API, but we're already in breaking-change land with #1117.

title: Add comit-rs to README
body: Couple of weeks back we replaced our hand-rolled network layer with libp2p, hence we would like to tell the world that we are now also using this awesome library :)

title: Kademlia: Fix status updates in KBuckets.
body:
`KBucket::update` does currently not correctly update the `first_connected_pos` before reinserting the node. This may result in previously connected nodes being considered disconnected and thus eligible for replacement by a pending node if the bucket is full and a new connected node is added.

This issue was introduced just recently in https://github.com/libp2p/rust-libp2p/pull/1117 and seems to be the actual cause for the debug assertion triggering as mentioned in https://github.com/libp2p/rust-libp2p/pull/1139.

The tests now check that `KBucket::update` preserves the status and ordering of all other nodes in the bucket (for arbitrary, non-empty buckets).

title: Update Kademlia protobuf.
body: Updates the Kademlia protobuf definitions and generated code to the [latest specification](https://github.com/libp2p/specs/blob/8b89dc2521b48bf6edab7c93e8129156a7f5f02c/kad-dht/README.md).

title: Add golem to the list of users
TCP transport: change listen address selection.
body:
Since every local socket address in the 127.0.0.0/8 space is looped back to 127.0.0.1/32 we should only have to report the later as the listen address. For other addresses we still attempt to discover host addresses when we encounter an unknown local address. We now also check that after
the host addresses have been reset that the address is now found, otherwise we produce an error.

title: Add OptionalUpgrade
body:
Necessary for Substrate.
I can't believe there was no way to do that.

title: Add secp256k1::SecretKey::to_bytes
body: Has been removed during the switch to `libsecp256k1` and there's no replacement.

title: new dockerfile
body:
- uses a new builder image 
- with `sccache`.

title: Kademlia: Optimise iteration over closest keys / entries.
body:
Based on https://github.com/libp2p/rust-libp2p/pull/1108.

The current implementation for finding the entries whose keys are closest to some target key in the Kademlia routing table involves copying the keys of all buckets into a new `Vec` which is then sorted based on the
distances of the entries to the target and turned into an iterator from which only a small number of elements (by default 20) are drawn.

This commit introduces an iterator for finding the closest keys (or entries) to a target that visits the buckets in the optimal order, based on the information contained in the distance bit-string representing the distance between the local key and the target (introduced in https://github.com/libp2p/rust-libp2p/pull/1108). I.e. the needed contents of the respectively next bucket are cloned and sorted only as more elements are drawn from the iterator.

Correctness is tested against full-table scans.

Because there was some overlap between the handling of pending nodes and the newly introduced iterator(s) in the sense that any access to a bucket should check for applicability of pending nodes to bring the bucket up-to-date, and there were a few TODOs left around the pending node handling, I refactored that part and added more tests. In particular, I did the following:

  * The (internal) bucket API for a single bucket was moved to `kbucket::bucket`, extracting large parts of code formerly directly embedded into the `Entry` API. That improves reuse and testability.
  * The (public) `Entry` API was moved to the `kbucket::entry` sub-module and simplified due to the first point. The `Entry` API now just mediates access to the internal bucket API.
  * The pending node handling reflects the following policy: `The nodes in a bucket are ordered from least-recently connected to most-recently connected`, i.e. a "connection-oriented" variant of what is described in the paper.

Due to refactorings the diffs are a bit large and I suggest the following (bottom-up) order for an effective review:

  1. The new `kbucket::bucket` module.
  2. The new `kbucket::entry` module.
  3. The new iterator(s) in the `kbucket` module and the new top-level functions `closest` and `closest_keys`, implementing the optimised bucket iteration. [Here is the relevant part in the `kbucket` module](https://github.com/libp2p/rust-libp2p/blob/7949879f73352b23a9e5e43c0f9fae1d312c2f46/protocols/kad/src/kbucket.rs#L209-L396).
  4. The remaining full diff of the `kbucket` and `behaviour` modules which adopt the rest of the code to the above changes. That should be quick after seeing all the previous changes.

title: Fix small todo in handled tasks
Kademlia: Correct XOR metric.
body:
**Note**: Sits on top of https://github.com/libp2p/rust-libp2p/pull/1101.

This PR addresses what I believe to be two issues with the current implementation and use of Kademlia's XOR metric:

  1. The distance is currently equated with the bucket index, i.e. `distance(a,b) - 1` is the index of the bucket into which either peer is put by the other. The result is a metric that is not unidirectional, as defined in the Kademlia paper and, as far as I could see, as it is implemented in e.g. libp2p-go and libp2p-js (see e.g. [here](https://github.com/libp2p/go-libp2p-kbucket/blob/master/keyspace/xor.go#L21-L44)), which is to interpret the result of the XOR as-is as an integer representing the distance. The bucket index is of course still determined by the distance.

  2. The current `KBucketsPeerId` trait and its instances compute distances between types with differing bit lengths as well as between types that re-hash all inputs (i.e. `KadHash`) and "plain" `PeerId`s or `Multihash`es, or even just between `PeerId`s or `Multihash`es. Such distances are incorrect as per the libp2p spec requirement that all distances be computed over the XOR of the SHA256 hashes of the inputs, be it peer IDs, multihashes, etc. The computed distances can even fall outside of the image of the metric used for the `KBucketsTable` and thus fall in the range of a non-existent bucket. In the latter case, such distances are not currently used as a bucket index - they can only occur temporarily in the context of comparing distances for the purpose of sorting peers - but that still seems very undesirable.

These issues are addressed in this PR as follows:

  * Unidirectionality of the XOR metric is restored by keeping the "full" integer representation of the bitwise XOR. The result is an XOR metric as defined in the paper and as computed by other libp2p implementations. This should also open the door to avoiding the  "full table scan" when searching for the keys closest to a given key - the ideal order in which to visit the buckets can be computed with the help of the distance bit string, which is something I'd like to try afterwards.

  * As a simplification and to make it easy to "do the right thing", the XOR metric is only defined on an opaque `kbucket::Key` type, partially derived from the current `KadHash`. `KadHash` and `KBucketsPeerId` are removed.

These changes do not affect the distribution of keys into buckets, i.e. the same peer ID (as a former `KadHash`) still falls into the same bucket, but restoring unidirectionality means e.g. that lookups for the closest peers for a specific key from different nodes will now converge towards the same set of closest peers, as described in the paper.

Tests for the properties of the XOR metric have been added and some existing tests tweaked.

title: Allow a path for WS multiaddresses
body:
Adds the possibility to add a URL path to multiaddress that contain `ws` or `wss`.

I'm doing this as a draft because I don't really know what to do with the string representation of these. At the moment, outputting such an address works, but parsing it back will fail.
